sub_questions.sub_question_text: Cultural practices through which historical information can be obtained include
Which of the following is the famous local museum in Tanzania?
In the process of evolution, a true man had appeared by about
The most crucial changes in the evolution of man were

options.A: bi-pedalism and development of the brain
options.C: division of labour and expansion of agriculture
options.D: establishment of settlements and domestication of crops

sub_questions.sub_question_text: Why the rulers of small Ngoni groups were able to defeat and consolidate their power to most of the East African societies?

options.A: Their female subjects were married by defeated tribes.
options.B: Their male subjects were agents of colonialism.
options.C: Their army used more magic power than weapons.
options.D: Their army had poor weapons like guns.
options.E: War captives were spared and recruited into Ngoni armies.

sub_questions.sub_question_text: Why the knowledge of iron-working was kept secret in some societies during pre-colonial period?

options.A: They wanted to develop division of labour.
options.B: Iron had the immediate use value to some societies.
options.C: They wanted to maintain monopoly of the blacksmiths.
options.D: They had plans of using it in making ornaments.
options.E: It enabled men to play a middleman's role in salt and gold.

sections.instructions: Answer all questions in this section.

sub_questions.sub_question_text: Draw a sketch map of East Africa and locate the following:
The headquarters of East African Community.
The capital city of a country whose president was overthrown in a coup in 1971.
The East African great slave market which was closed in 1873.
The headquarters of the Portuguese rule.
The region in Tanganyika which was the best reservoir of labour during the colonial period.
Outline five effects of colonial education in East Africa.

Arrange the following statements in chronological order by writing number 1 to 5 beside the item number in your answer booklet.

(i) In December 1963, the British handed political power to the Arab minority.

(ii) It was soon followed by the union between Tanganyika and Zanzibar forming the United Republic of Tanzania.

(iii) The 1964 Zanzibar revolution was the second attempt made to bring about real political independence.

(iv) This event was an important step towards the achievement of East African Unity.

(v) The revolution was intended to transfer power to the majority.

The items i-v consists of four sentences which form a complete historical meaning. One of the sentences is missing. Identify the missing sentence from the sentences given after each set of items (A - E) and write its letter beside the item number.

1. In the 13th century, Ghana crumbled.
2. Its position was taken by several smaller states.
3. Among these was the former kingdom of Kangaba.
4. ____________________

options.A: Kangaba grew up to become the empire of Songhai.
options.B: Kangaba was led by Askia Mohamed.
options.C: Kangaba grew up to become the empire of Mali.
options.D: Kangaba was led by Osei Tutu.
options.E: Kangaba disengaged from the grip of the Forest states.

sub_questions.sub_question_text:
1. There were few communal societies in East Africa by 1850.
2. ____________________
3. These people still lived in shifting groups of hunters and gatherers.
4. They had few external interactions and maintained their mode of production.

options.A: These include the Hadzabe of Tanzania and Tindiga of Uganda.
options.B: These include the Hadzabe of Uganda and Teuso of Kenya.
options.C: These include the Teuso and Dorobo of Kenya.
options.D: These include the Tindinga of Kenya and Dorobo of Tanzania.
options.E: These include the Teuso of Uganda and Dorobo of Kenya.

sub_questions.sub_question_text:
1. Post-colonial efforts to develop the commercial sector were greatly influenced by the colonial legacy.
2. In Kenya, private ownership was greatly consolidated after independence.
3. ____________________
4. In Tanzania, various efforts have been made to place the commercial sector in the hands of the people.

options.A: In Uganda, Milton Obote launched a Common Man's Charter in 1976.
options.B: Private enterprises were confiscated from the Arabs in Uganda.
options.C: In Uganda, Idd Amin repatriated most of the Asian traders and placed their commercial enterprises in the hands of his military clique.
options.D: Portuguese wholesale traders controlled the commercial sector in Uganda.
options.E: Commercial institutions were closed in Uganda due to bankruptcies.

sub_questions.sub_question_text:
1. Indirect rule enabled the colonial government to solve the problem of the shortage of white personnel.
2. The few white officials could not by themselves administer large and populous colonies without the assistance of local agents.
3. ____________________
4. It also promoted divisions along ethnic lines which kept the colonial subjects divided and easy to rule.

options.A: It made the French colonial administrators act only as supervisors.
options.B: It was a useful system during the struggle for independence.
options.C: It was initiated by Fredrick Lugard in northern Angola.
options.D: It allowed the Africans to register as French citizens.
options.E: It enabled the colonial state to collect tribute and taxes.

sub_questions.sub_question_text:
1. After the 1886 agreement, responsibility for administering Kenya was entrusted to the British Consul in Zanzibar.
2. However, in 1888 this responsibility was transferred to William Mackinnon's East African Company.
3. In the same year, the company received a royal charter.
4. ____________________

options.A: It was named British East African Protectorate.
options.B: It was renamed the Imperial British East African Company.
options.C: It was called the Royal Niger Company.
options.D: It became known as German East African Company.
options.E: It was known as Rhodes' British Company.

sections.instructions: Answer three (3) questions from this section.

questions.question_text: Explain six effects of the pre-colonial contacts between the people of Africa and Asia.
Elaborate six reasons which made the Boers to escape to escape the Southern African Cape between 1830 and 1850.
Analyse six methods that were used by the imperialists in imposing colonial rule in Africa.
How were the East African colonies affected by the First World War? Give six points to support your answer.
Examine six factors which enabled Tanganyika to attain her independence earlier than Kenya.
"Migrant labourers were very useful to the capitalists during colonial economy in Africa." Substantiate this statement by giving six points.
